occurrences.line_text: The day that first of Priame she was seene,
And day and night her dores to all stand open wide.
Which mariage make; that day too farre did seeme:
But ere that wished day his beame disclosd,
One day vnto me came in friendly mood,
One day to worke her to his will more neare,
For he has vowd, to beene aueng'd that day,
(That day it selfe him seemed all too long:)
What dismall day hath lent this cursed light,
Day and night keeping wary watch and ward,
An vgly feend, more fowle then dismall day,
The hew thereof: for vew of chearefull day
And warily awaited day and night,
To wonder at the sight: for till that day,
After so wicked deed why liu'st thou lenger day?
And said, Paynim, this is thy dismall day;
I liue this day, and see my foes subdewd,
Day and night duely keeping watch and ward,
For day and night it brent, ne ceased not,
And named it Albion. But later day
That well can witnesse yet vnto this day
What colour were their waters that same day,
How oft that day did sad Brunchildis see
His daughter gan despise his drouping day,
But lost his sword, yet to be seene this day.
Yet true it is, that long before that day
Through which into the world the dawning day
To see a cruell fight doen by the Prince this day.
They battred day and night, and entraunce did awate.
Ne once did yield it respit day nor night,
Of feeling pleasures, with which day and night
And had not bene remoued many a day;
Which afterwards did rule the night and day;
In springing flowre the image of thy day;
So passeth, in the passing of a day,
Dauncing and reueling both day and night,
With which faire Britomart gaue light vnto the day.
T'abridg their iourney long, and lingring day;
One day it fortuned, faire Britomart
And all the day, when as thine equall peares,
The same one day, as me misfortune led,
Earely the morrow next, before that day
In a deepe delue, farre from the vew of day,
But there doe toyle and trauell day and night,
And darkesome night he eke could turne to day:
That to this day for terror of his fame,
Ne other to himselfe is knowne this day,
From where the day out of the sea doth spring,
And dreaded name shall giue in that sad day:
The famous Dumarin; who on a day
One day of Proteus by his mightie spell,
For thy she gaue him warning euery day,
For day discouers all dishonest wayes,
Our life is day, but death with darknesse doth begin.
O when will day then turne to me againe,
And yeeld her roome to day, that can it gouerne well.
And in lewd slouth to wast his carelesse day:
From Faery court, where I haue many a day
Liues none this day, that may with her compare
She on a day, as she pursewd the chace
It was vpon a Sommers shynie day,
Vnwares had borne two babes, as faire as springing day.
About him day and night, which doe require,
But all the day before the sunny rayes
And earely ere the dawning day appeard,
Yet neuer learned he such seruice, till that day.
Till on a day, as he disposed was
And next to none, after that happie day,
Cannot two fairer Cities find this day,
Ne doth he suffer her, nor night, nor day,
One day, as he forpassed by the plaine
Which all good knights, that armes do beare this day,
Till on a day the Satyres her espide
All day they daunced with great lustihed,
Nine times he heard him come aloft ere day,
He wooed her, till day spring he espyde;
Suffred, these seuen monethes day in secret den
In dolefull darkenesse from the vew of day,
And day and night afflicts with mortall paine,
Dying each day with inward wounds of dolours dart.
Out of her secret stand, that day for to out weare.
All that day she outwore in wandering,
At this same furrowes end, till a new day:
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
In perilous fight, she neuer ioyed day,
The very selfe same day that she was wedded,
Whereby great riches gathered manie a day,
This day, to wreake the dammage by thee donne:
The open wrongs, thou doest me day by day;
The open wrongs, thou doest me day by day;
There they I weene would fight vntill this day,
This happie day I haue to greete you well,
One day, when all that troupe of warlike wooers
There on a day a noble youthly knight
The day was set, that all might vnderstand,
That day, the dreddest day that liuing wight
That day, the dreddest day that liuing wight
To view and deeme the deedes of armes that day;
Till that at length vpon th'appointed day,
Which doughty Triamond had wrought that day,
So Satyrane that day was iudg'd to beare the bell.
So that the doome was to another day differd.
The last day came, when all those knightes againe
Full many deedes that day were shewed plaine:
The doughtiest knight that liv'd that day, and most of might.
So he continued all that day throughout,
Like as in sommers day when raging heat
The prize, to knights of Maydenhead that day,
The same one day, when she her selfe disposd
That Satyrane the first day best had donne:
For since the day that they created beene,
That hath this day so many so vnmanly shent.
The more it gauld, and grieu'd him night and day,
That neither day nor night from working spared,
The which in Lipari doe day and night
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
And now the day out of the Ocean mayne
The next day, as he on his way did ride,
That almost had against you trespassed this day.
This other day (sayd he) a stranger knight
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
Till on a day as through a desert wyld
But all she did was but to weare out day.
Which many a knight had sought so many a day.
This dismall day hath thee a caytiue made,
So on a day vnweeting vnto wight,
Where yet vntouched till this present day,
For on a day, by fortune as it fell,
But alwaies wept and wailed night and day,
Till on a day, as in his wonted wise
And euery day for guerdon of her song,
Vpon a day as she him sate beside,
Till on a day as through that wood he rode,
Tho soone as day discouered heauens face
This Gyants daughter came vpon a day
From day to day she woo'd and prayd him fast,
From day to day she woo'd and prayd him fast,
So on a day as by the flowrie marge
From that day forth in peace and ioyous blis,
For since the day that first with deadly wound
And time to steale, the threasure of mans day;
Who day and night did watch and duely ward,
Where as my loue was lodged day and night:
And darkenesse dredd, that neuer viewed day,
Ne euer from the day the night descride,
Before that day her wooed to his bed;
They all on him this day attended well;
And ioy likewise this solemne day to see?
One day, as she to shunne the season whot,
All which that day in order seemly good
Her siluer feet, faire washt against this day:
In which his wretched loue lay day and night,
But weeping day and night, did him attend,
Vpon a day she found this gentle childe,
Well prou'd in that same day, when Ioue those Gyants quelled.
That euer I this dismall day did see:
This day as I in solace sate hereby
He for a twelue moneths day shall in despight
None other way will I this day betake,
By which as they did trauell on a day,
To tell the glorie of the feast that day,
Full many deedes of armes that day were donne,
But all that day the greatest prayse redounded
The second day, so soone as morrow light
And there all day continew'd cruell fight,
That Marinell that day deserued best.
The third day came, that should due tryall lend
And all these knights, which that day armour bore,
To whom that day they should the girlond yield.
Approu'd that day, that she all others did excell.
That what he did that day, he did it not
What strokes, what dreadfull stoure it stird this day:
That neuer word from that day forth he spoke.
Whereof no brauer president this day
By what good right doe you withhold this day?
Or else what other deadly dismall day
And made the scorne of Knighthod this same day.
Weary of toile and trauell of that day,
For the rebuke, which she sustain'd that day,
As she had seene that day a disauenterous sight.
S   O soone as day forth dawning from the East,
In which he had bene trayned many a day,
But it tormented her both day and night:
And with wide glauncing words, one day she thus him proued.
Vnworthy sure (quoth he) of better day,
One day her Ladie, calling her apart,
One day, when as she long had sought for ease
I wote when ye did watch both night and day
By this the day with dampe was ouercast,
Vntill she spide the lampe of lightsome day,
Ne day nor night did euer idly rest;
Which he vnto her people does each day,
He is prouokt, and stird vp day and night
Iustice that day of wrong her selfe had wroken,
And there the Prince, as victour of that day,
And earnestly besought, to wend that day
Stood open wyde to all men day and night;
Whom seeing all in armour bright as day,
Vpon Ioues iudgement seat wayt day and night,
Which till this day mongst many liuing are,
Ne day nor night did sleepe, t'attend them on,
And all his armours readie dight that day,
That same is it, which fought for you this day.
Then all the people, which beheld that day,
On which long way he rode, ne euer day did rest.
And now he hath to her prefixt a day,
He day and night doth ward both far and wide,
For from the day that he thus did it leaue,
That in one day they with the coast did fall;
The morrow next, ne gaue him longer day;
The morrow next, that was the dismall day,
Most squalid garments, fit for such a day,
There wayting for the Tyrant, till it was farre day.
And day and night employ'd his busie paine
Whenas by chaunce he met vppon a day
Of all this day on ground, that breathen liuing spright.
He this same day, as I that way did come
As doth a Steare, in heat of sommers day,
What haps to day to me, to morrow may to you.
Where, as this day I was enraunging it,
This day, as he and I together roade
To lend him day his better right to trie,
For since the day that armes I first did reare,
The rather since that fortune hath this day
The morrow next, when day gan to vplooke,
Calidore rising vp as fresh as day,
The day before by iust auengement
Where he arriuing with the fall of day,
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
The morrow next, so soone as ioyous day
Vpon a day he cast abrode to wend,
So all that day in wandring vainely he did spend.
But day and night did vexe her carefull thought,
And faithfully did serue both day and night,
Vpon a day as on their way they went,
Vpon a day as they the time did waite,
The wretchedst Dame, that liue this day on ground;
Their ranckling wounds, & euery day them duely drest.
One day, as he was searching of their wounds,
Now smyling smoothly, like to sommers day,
Swore by his sword, that neither day nor weeke
For on a day, when Cupid kept his court,
But day, that doth discouer bad and good,
That day nor night he suffred him to rest,
There on a day as he pursew'd the chace,
And caroling her name both day and night,
And sate there still, vntill the flying day
That wild the damzell rise; the day did now expyre.
For so great kindnesse as he found that day,
And all the day, to what I list, I doe attend.
And euery day, her companie to gaine,
With the faire Pastorella euery day,
One day when as the shepheard swaynes together
One day as he did raunge the fields abroad,
Vpon her yuory forehead that same day
Vppon this hill, and daunce there day and night:
So farre as doth the daughter of the day,
One day as they all three together went
From that day forth she gan him to affect,
It fortuned one day, when Calidore
Where day and night she nought did but lament
One day as he did all his prisoners vew,
From that day forth he kyndnesse to her showed,
Ne day nor night he suffred her to rest,
But her all night did watch, and all the day molest.
That euer I did liue, this day to see,
This dismall day, and was not dead before,
But gently waking them, gaue them the time of day.
So there all day they bode, till light the sky forsooke.
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
How many flyes in whottest sommers day
Appointed to attend her dewly day and night.
Some were of dogs, that barked day and night,
For aye in darkenesse, which day light doth shonne:
In which that wicked wight his dayes doth weare:
His wanton dayes that euer loosely led,
Banisht from liuing wights, our wearie dayes we waste.
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
And felly gnarre, vntill dayes enemy
Her wicked dayes with wretched knife did end,
Where he his better dayes hath wasted all.
This dayes ensample hath this lesson deare
There all my dayes he traind me vp in vertuous lore.
To draw thy dayes forth to their last degree?
That he desirde to end his wretched dayes:
Did spend their dayes in doing godly thing:
Dwelt fortie dayes vpon; where writ in stone
two dayes incessantly:
He might for memorie of that dayes ruth,
Does waste his dayes in darke obscuritee,
And henceforth by this dayes ensample trow,
Full many doughtie knights he in his dayes
And honours suit my vowed dayes do spend,
For now three dayes of men were full outwrought,
An happie man in his first dayes he was,
For till his dayes, the chiefe dominion
The which was dew in his dead fathers dayes:
The iustest man and trewest in his dayes,
Who ioyd his dayes in great tranquillity,
For skill in Musicke of all in her dayes,
With which the world did in those dayes abound:
So end of that Carles dayes, and his owne paines did make.
Two dayes now in that sea he sayled has,
The lether-winged Bat, dayes enimy,
His dayes, his goods, his bodie he did spend:
Where through long watch, & late dayes weary toile,
But by ensample of the last dayes losse,
Her wretched dayes in dolour she mote wast,
Till death make one end of my dayes and miserie.
He shall his dayes with peace bring to his earthly In.
Late dayes ensample, which these eyes beheld,
Few dayes before, had gotten a great pray
But if the heauens did his dayes enuie,
Halfe of thy dayes doest lead in horrour hideous.
Dayes dearest children be the blessed seed,
Fiue dayes there be, since he (they say) was slaine,
The comfort of her age and weary dayes,
But all my dayes am like to wast in vaine,
Thy dayes abridge, through proofe of puissance,
For all his dayes he drownes in priuitie,
In dolefull thraldome all his dayes to dwell?
My natiue soile haue left, my dayes to spend
As if his dayes were come to their last reach.
O spare thy happy dayes, and them apply
Which were whilome captiued in their dayes
His dearest loue, the comfort of his dayes,
What time the dayes with scorching heat abound,
That was the learnedst Ladie in her dayes,
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
Therefore desirous th'end of all their dayes
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
So did they surely during all their dayes,
To draw their dayes vnto the vtmost date,
The third dayes prize vnto that straunger Knight,
his dayes in dole doth lead.
Sith now of dayes such temperance is rare
Of present dayes, which are corrupted sore,
The third was Brunell, famous in his dayes;
Which this dayes honour sau'd to Marinell;
Spending their ioyous dayes and gladfull nights,
I rew that thus thy better dayes are drowned
Her dayes in warre, yet (weet thou) was not borne
And his abridged dayes in dolour wast,
For houres but dayes; for weekes, that passed were,
Doe spend my dayes, and bend my carelesse wit
And through the long experience of his dayes,
And her good dayes in dolorous disgrace:
Haile iolly shepheard, which thy ioyous dayes
As he hath sung of thee in all his dayes,
That mak'st thy selfe his dayes-man, to prolong
By this the drouping day-light gan to fade
A thousand yong ones, which she dayly fed,
With which bare wretched wights he dayly clad,
Here haunts that feend, and does his dayly spoyle,
All were she dayly with himselfe in place,
That death him did awaite in dayly wretchednesse.
And dayly how through hardy enterprize,
Still did they striue, and dayly disagree;
And dayly warre against his foeman moues,
Whilest Romanes dayly did the weake subdew:
And dayly spectacle of sad decay:
With which they dayly made most dreadfull battery.
Of his bad deeds, which dayly he increast,
Dayly she dressed him, and did the best
Whiles dayly plaisters to his wound she layd,
And dayly more offensiue vnto each degree.
And all dissention, which doth dayly grow
Yet he to her did dayly seruice more,
And dayly more deceiued was thereby;
Yet in his soundest sleepe, his dayly feare
And dayly feasting both in bowre and hall,
And dayly yet thou doest the same repayre:
Ne dayly food did take, ne nightly sleepe,
And dayly he his wrongs encreaseth more,
Approuing dayly to their noble eyes
To that foule feend, who dayly doth attend
The litle that I haue, growes dayly more
Dayly beholding the faire Pastorell,
With dayly seruice and attendance dew,
The warlike youthes on dayntie couches layd,
Or that may dayntiest fantasie aggrate,
Their days mote be abridged through their corage stout.
That since their days such louers were not found elswhere.
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
Became starke blind, and all his senses daz'd,
That could haue dazd the rash beholders sight,
That daz'd the eyes of all, as with exceeding light.
And with their brightnesse daz'd the straunge beholders eye.
While flashing beames do daze his feeble eyen,
But shewd by outward signes, that dread her sence did daze.
False Labyrinthes, fond runners eyes to daze;
The glaunce whereof their dimmed eies would daze,
And on those guilefull dazed eyes of his
It dimmes the dazed eyen, and daunts the senses quight.
To haue returnd, but dazed were his eyne,
His feeble eyne, with too much brightnesse dazed,
Assotted had his sense, or dazed was his eie.
The whiles the passing brightnes her fraile sences dazed.
That he began to doubt his dazeled sight,
But would be dazled with exceeding light.
And dead as liuing euer him ador'd:
Great Gorgon, Prince of darknesse and dead night,
Dead long ygoe I wote thou haddest bin,
There lies he now with foule dishonour dead,
Then turning to his Lady, dead with feare her found.
Her seeming dead he found with feigned feare,
Nigh dead with feare, and faint astonishment,
Dead sculs & bones of men, whose life had gone astray.
Dead is Sans-foy, his vitall paines are past,
And with Sans-foyes dead dowry you endew.
When Ioue auizd, that could the dead reuiue,
A donghill of dead carkases he spide,
Would faine haue dyde: dead was his hart within,
A liue or dead: and forward forth doth pas,
That brought not backe the balefull body dead;
And foster father of the Gyant dead;
Fled fast away, halfe dead with dying feare:
The sixt had charge of them now being dead,
All in his hand, euen dead we honour should.
Ah dearest God me graunt, I dead be not defould.
Had charge the tender Orphans of the dead
Dead was it sure, as sure as death in deed,
For vnto life the dead it could restore,
That to the earth him droue, as stricken dead,
Who thereby dead that balefull Beast did deeme,
For dead now was their foe, which them forrayed late.
But when they came, where that dead Dragon lay,
Halfe dead through feare, her litle babe reuyld,
Or false or trew, or liuing or else dead,
Liue thou, and to thy mother dead attest,
Of death and labour lay, halfe dead, halfe quicke,
The dead corse of an armed knight was spred,
Loe this dead corpse, that lies here vnderneath,
The charme fulfild, dead suddenly he downe did sincke.
The dead knights sword out of his sheath he drew,
And in dead parents balefull ashes bred,
Why liuest thou, dead dog, a lenger day,
Tract of his foot: then dead through great affright
Him deeming dead, as then he seemd in sight,
And dead mens bones, which round about were flong,
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
Dead sleeping Poppy, and blacke Hellebore,
Thus for to blot the honour of the dead,
Bad therefore I him deeme, that thus lies dead on field.
For why should a dead dog be deckt in armour bright?
Of vile reuenge. To spoile the dead of weed
In whose dead face he red great magnanimity.
To wreake your wrath on this dead seeming knight,
Why should not that dead carrion satisfie
That doth against the dead his hand vpreare,
Therefore by Termagaunt thou shalt be dead.
Full liuely is the semblaunt, though the substance dead.
Faire Sir (said he) if in that picture dead
The faire Sabrina almost dead with feare,
His sonne Riuallo his dead roome did supply,
The which was dew in his dead fathers dayes:
Made of a dead mans skull, that seem'd a ghastly sight.
Or his dead corse should fall vpon the flore;
But his dead corse vpon the flore fell nathemore.
Tho when he felt him dead, a downe he kest
Me leuer were with point of foemans speare be dead.
Chaunged thy liuely cheare, and liuing made thee dead?
Thou her afford, full shortly I her dead shall see.
Of his late puissaunce, his Image dead,
Bene they all dead, and laid in dolefull herse?
If they be dead, then woe is me therefore:
To see friends graue, the[m] dead the graue selfe to engrosse.
Belphebe finds him almost dead,
Till him aliue or dead she did inuent.
They three be dead with shame, the Squire liues with renowne.
That Ladies all may follow her ensample dead.
Of life, she put a Spright to rule the carkasse dead.
Against the silly clowne, who dead through feare,
And offrest sacrifice vnto the dead:
For dead, I surely doubt, thou maist aread
He fainted, and was almost dead with feare,
Lewd Losse of Time, and Sorrow seeming dead,
He fell halfe dead; next stroke him should haue slaine,
In wilfull anguish, and dead heauinesse,
Was dead with feare, nathlesse as neede required,
And being dead in vaine yet many striue:
That downe he fell as dead in all mens sight:
Yet dead he was not, yet he sure did die,
Him dead behight, as he to all appeard,
So both at once fell dead vpon the field,
For very gall, that rather wholly dead
I vow, you dead or liuing not to leaue,
For she deare Ladie all the way was dead,
Emong the liuing, or emong the dead?
The other almost dead and desperate
Then did her glorious flowre wex dead and wan,
Sith then (sayd he) ye both the dead deny,
Let both the dead and liuing equally
To witnesse to the world, that she by him is dead.
Aliue, then to him selfe be shared dead;
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
And eke their dame halfe dead did hide her self for feare.
Which some hath put to shame, and many done be dead.
And dead long since in dolorous distresse,
And left there dead. Meane while the other Knight
